sessions.title: Welcome from the organizers
Keep up, without crashing out
sessions.description:
We live in a world of change. We are constantly facing new technology, roles and responsibilities are changing and it's easy to feel that you're either falling behind or getting burned out. At conferences we learn lots of new stuff that we would like to try out. At the same time we need to deliver high quality in our regular jobs. How? Demanding that all professional development comes on top of our normal workload or needs to happen in our free time is not sustainable.

I'll give you effective learning strategies and clever tricks for learning at work. This way you can become an asset to the team, your boss will see the advantage of sending you to conferences and you can spend your free time on the stuff that gives you energy.

sessions.title: Break
Break
Lunch
Can we architecture our way out of a chaotic reality?
sessions.description:
In the IT industry we have this idea that we can remove our systems from the chaos of real life, either through careful consideration of architecture or attention to detail in modelling. Thus we should create simple, or at least maintainable systems. 

We all know this isn’t what we face in our professional lives, where even the seemingly smallest detail can cause huge delays and complications. 

Join me in viewing system development and evolving systems through the lens of the chaos of reality and societal development.

sessions.title: From Legacy to Rust: A Real-World Backend Migration Story
sessions.description:
Rust is the most admired programming language.
But is it production ready? 
And is it possible to hire developers?
Can you convince management to use it?

This talk will cover our story at Zrch, where we use Rust as the main language in our backend. We will share our learnings, our migration approach and the challenges we overcame along the way.

What you'll learn:
• How our first attempt to rewrite legacy code failed (and why)
• The strategies that made our Rust migration successful
• Pain points of Rust
• Interactions with other languages
• Building a Rust team: hiring  and onboarding challenges
• Leveraging AI tools for Rust development
• If time permits, we will briefly cover frontend aspects

Whether you're evaluating a new language (like Rust) for your next project or already committed to the journey, this session offers practical insights from a team that's been there.

sessions.title: Hack, Learn, Improve: Inside Storebrand’s Bug Bounty Experience
sessions.description:
Over the past years, Storebrand has actively engaged with ethical hackers through its bug bounty program, uncovering and mitigating vulnerabilities across a wide range of systems. In this talk, we’ll share what we’ve learned from real-world reports (from surprising edge cases to recurring patterns) and how these insights have strengthened both our technology and our culture.

We’ll highlight some of the most interesting findings, discuss how we improved our detection and response processes, and reflect on what it takes to build genuine collaboration between developers and security researchers. Whether you’re a developer, tester, or security professional, this session offers practical lessons on turning bugs into opportunities for better security.

sessions.title: Break
To be announced
sessions.description: To be announced

sessions.title: Day ends
Robust and idempotent build pipelines using nix
sessions.description: Build pipelines can be challenging to get right, they can be brittle and hard to debug, often suffering from 'work on my machine' syndrome. We can eliminate most of this headache by adding nix to the mix

sessions.title: Designing Transparent Tech for Kids: Why Explainability Matters
sessions.description: Children today use apps that collect health data, monitor behavior, and adapt learning – often without understanding how or why. In this lightning talk, we explore the critical need for explainability in school technology. Why must tech be transparent not just for engineers, but also for students, teachers, and parents? What does it mean to design for understanding – and what are the risks when we don’t?

sessions.title: Going Old School - Moving from the cloud to my own server
sessions.description:
How is it like going back to the good old days of early 2000, where anything ran on it's own server?

I will share my experience of moving away from the cloud and back to a virtual private server. What can you get, and what do you lose? What does it mean in terms of deployment processes, security, robustness, scalability, privacy and compliance and performance?

...and the big question of course: Would I do it again?

sessions.title: People with agendas
sessions.description:
Alexander Hamilton wrote a warning in 1787, that looking for peace and harmony among neighbouring states is to disregard the uniform course of human events. 
There is a war in Europe, we are in a still escalating hybrid situation with Russia and we know our code and data can and will be weaponized if the powers that be decide to do so. 
Moreover, big tech are pushing their own agenda, they do not like EU regulations that hit them in the pocket but they do love our money. At the same time they hold incredible power in terms of technology that cannot be easily replaced and enormous amounts of our data that cannot be easily moved. 
What the f ... do we do?

sessions.title: Deployment i 2025 - serverløs i praksis
sessions.description: Deploy pleide å bety pipelines, CI-skript og YAML-filer. I dag kan det være så enkelt som å trykke på en knapp. Jeg skal vise hvordan moderne infrastukturplatformer som Vercel har gjort det mulig å shippe en full webapp på minutter, uten å tenke på servere, infrastruktur eller DevOps.

sessions.title: Build your own cloud
sessions.description: In light of todays weakened trust in the "tech giants" and the focus on privacy and security, we will explore an alternative to the "spin it up in {Insert cloud provider here}" solution. In this talk, we will take a look at various open source tools and software that can be used to build a competitive hosting platform. Do we have to give up the advantages that the hyperscalers provide? Are there specific benefits to building it yourself? Is this only relevant for large companies with their own DevOps teams? These are questions we will explore in this session.

sessions.title: Scaling Varnish on AWS - How Norway's Leading News Platform Handles Millions of Requests Per Second
sessions.description: Norway's largest newspaper vg.no successfully migrated from physical data centers to Varnish Cache on AWS, implementing large-scale clusters in Kubernetes to serve millions of requests per second. Get to know more about how the  migration delivered improved performance through optimized caching strategies and auto-scaling, while significantly reducing infrastructure costs and enhancing operational flexibility.

sessions.title: npm install malware
sessions.description: Npm is perhaps the biggest spreader of malware targeting developers. I'll go over how malware can be spread on npm and some ways we can protect ourselves

sessions.title: Avoid the usability cliff. Create a stairway to heavenly complexity.
sessions.description:
“Simple things should be simple, complex things should be possible” – Alan Kay.

This is a good rule of thumb for anyone creating digital tools, no matter if you are working on the API-level or with the user interface. But it is only a start. You need to make sure that the path from simple to complex is a good stairway and not a steep cliff, making sure that the increase in user effort matches the increase in perceived value.

In this lightning talk I will show concrete examples from both my own projects and well known applications, as well as demonstrating some techniques to make sure users don’t feel cheated for the effort they put in.

sessions.title: Font for thought: set it once, say it well
sessions.description:
Fonts, line heights and… fewer headaches? Yes, please.

Join us for a fast-paced dive into how a solid typography system can save time, reduce team debates, and make onboarding a breeze.

Because arguing about font sizes isn’t a sprint goal!

sessions.title: Frå kontor til kjøkkenbord: fjernarbeid og arbeidsmiljø
sessions.description: Fjernarbeid har blitt ein stor del av kvardagen for oss som jobbar i IT. Fjenarbeid stiller nye krav til korleis ein organiserer arbeidet, og det påverker arbeidsmiljøet på godt og på vondt. Kva seier forskinga om fjernarbeid, og korleis kan ein få fjernarbeid til å fungere godt i praksis?

sessions.title: Cognitive load is misunderstood
sessions.description:
Is experiencing a high cognitive load always bad? Does it make sense to talk about cognitive load on the team level? Are we better able to think about the big problems if we offload the small ones?

Cognitive Load Theory has risen in popularity the last few years, and rightly so! Developers and architects have much to learn from psychology. But with popularity comes misunderstandings, since few ever take the time to read the actual research. To rid us of the misunderstandings I will take you through the concepts you can use to develop a clearer vocabulary when talking about cognitive load.

sessions.title: Methodology as a Straitjacket
sessions.description:
At some point, we started treating methodology like religion. Agile became dogma. Design Thinking turned into ritual. Double Diamond became an icon people worship without fully understanding what it means. Everyone talks about “doing it right”, but very few remember why we are doing any of it in the first place.

People fill out canvases like they are sitting an exam, and panic when reality refuses to fit the template. Teams get stuck in ceremonies they actively dislike, but keep doing them because “it says so in the book”. And when someone finally asks, “Does this actually make sense?”, they are labelled difficult.

We don’t need to burn all the methodologies to the ground. Most of them were created for good reasons. We need to remember who the methods are supposed to serve, and stop pretending reality should bend to fit the process. Use what works, drop the rest, think for yourself.

Let’s be honest here. None of us is doing pure Agile, real Double Diamond, textbook Design Thinking, or whatever methodology happens to be in vogue this month. And that is the whole point.

The emperor is naked. And sometimes, that is perfectly fine.

sessions.title: Help! I've Become My Own Customer!
sessions.description:
You are passionately enthusiastic about code and proud of the good quality you deliver in every pull request. You are also a curious soul who thrives deep down in the rabbit hole of your hobby. All hobbies cost time. Most cost money. Some cost a lot of money, but you are smart. You find a way to make money from your hobby. You need an online store. You can write the code and pay in the time spent, but how much time do you really want to pay?

This is something Christian has pondered a lot over the last 4 years since he started a coffee roastery in his garage. The hobby wasn't supposed to become a part-time job, it was just supposed to be fun. And what's more fun than cutting corners, taking shortcuts, and defining for yourself what is good enough?

In this lightning talk, Christian will talk about the experiences he has gained from his quest to become Bergen's most caffeine-obsessed developer, and how he has gained more empathy for product owners along the way.

sessions.title: Do You Really Have a Team?
sessions.description:
Unpacking the Illusion of Teamwork in Agile Development.

Many software teams claim to be “Agile,” but in reality, they operate as loosely connected individuals rather than cohesive, high-performing teams. In this talk, we’ll explore the illusion of teamwork—how daily standups, ticket ownership, and even Agile rituals can mask siloed behavior and developer ego. Drawing from real-world examples and Agile principles, we’ll contrast dysfunctional patterns with the traits of truly collaborative teams. You’ll leave with practical strategies to foster trust, shared ownership, and team-level accountability—whether you’re a developer, Scrum Master, or leader.

sessions.title: Unplug to Recharge: The Hidden Power of Off-Screen Time
sessions.description:
After years working in PR, IT Operations, and DevOps, and spending time as a Scrum Master along the way, I’ve learned that uptime isn’t everything, especially when it comes to humans. When I started my software engineering studies at 30, I thought the key to catching up was spending more hours in front of the screen. It wasn’t.
I discovered that my most creative ideas often appeared when I stepped away from the keyboard. In this lightning talk, I’ll show how taking breaks can boost creativity, sharpen focus, and bring clarity to complex problems in the fast-paced day-to-day of a developer. You’ll leave with a few simple, evidence-based habits for building rest into your schedule, because time spent off the screen isn’t lost – it is maintenance.

sessions.title: You too can build you own smart mirror!
sessions.description:
A few years ago some people at work built a smart mirror for use at a conference. Maybe you've seen it? It had face recognition, personalized content, weather forecast, bus schedule, and so on.

Since there was nothing stopping us, we followed up by building smaller versions to bring home with us, and mine quickly became a popular "member of the family".

Now I will show you how easily you too can build your own smart mirror!

sessions.title: How to find the "million in the forest" using open data and geo-tools
sessions.description:
In recent years, Horde AS has organized a real treasure hunt - a box hidden somewhere in the Norwegian wilderness, streamed live online. The clues were few, but the camera streamed continuously, and the first person to find and reach the location won the prize worth over one million kroner.

But how do you even begin to narrow down where the box could be - when all you have is a livestream from an unknown location?

Inspired by this, I`ve developed my own tools to help with the search; called FALKE+BLIKK.

In short it`s a "investigation toolkit" for combining open data with automated integration into a GIS (Geographic Information System). Bringing both worlds together in one unified solution.

Welcome down into my rabbit hole. Through some detective work, coding and GIS we`ll take a look at some of my lessons to build a toolbox for a modern day treasure hunt.

sessions.title: Du er ikke Dum - En Forskningsbasert Metode for å Lære Alt Mulig
sessions.description:
Er du lei av å lese ting igjen og igjen, og én uke senere har du glemt alt sammen?  Da gjør du én eller to vanlige feil som motvirker diin evne til å huske det du lærer. 

I denne morsomme, jordnære og konkrete presentasjonen vil Peter gå gjennom de to vanligste, men dårligste metodene folk bruker når de skal lære seg ting, og forklare hvorfor de fungerer så dårlig. 

I tillegg vil Peter gå gjennom fire enkle metoder som forskning har funnet er mest effektivt for å lære nye konsepter, og hvordan enkelt integrere de i en arbeidshverdag. 

Peter baserer innholdet i presentasjonen på akademiske artikler, men presenterer innholdet på en lett og forståelig måte, med bruk av håndtegnede tegninger og morsomme figurer. 

Å lære å lære er en av de viktigste ferdighetene en kan ta med seg i arbeidslivet, så dette er en presentasjon du ikke vil gå glipp av.

sessions.title: A close reading of Computer Machinery and Intelligence
sessions.description:
In the age of the LLM, the Turing Test is more relevant than ever. But what *is* the Turing Test? How did Turing envision the Imitation Game, as he called it, and what does he see as its greatest limitations? 

In this session, Felienne will take you on wild ride through a seminal paper in computer science, philosophy and computation.

sessions.title: MCP: Universalkontakt for AI eller snarvei til Skynet?
sessions.description:
Model Context Protocol (MCP) er i ferd med å bli en kraftig måte å koble AI-modeller med verktøy, data og systemer på — tenk på det som USB-C for AI. Ved å standardisere hvordan modeller samhandler med eksterne tjenester, åpner MCP døren til mer kapable og kontekstsensitive applikasjoner.

I dette foredraget viser jeg hva MCP er, hva det muliggjør, og hvorfor det er viktig. Gjennom et konkret case med en MCP-server bygget for Entur demonstrerer jeg hvordan slike servere fungerer i praksis og hvilke muligheter de gir. Men med stor kraft følger også risiko: jeg utforsker sikkerhetsutfordringer knyttet til å gi AI direkte tilgang til eksterne systemer, og trekker paralleller til reelle hendelser fra plattformer som WhatsApp og GitHub.

Avslutningsvis deler jeg strategier for hvordan utviklere og organisasjoner kan utnytte MCPs potensial på en trygg måte, og unngå de mest kritiske fallgruvene.

sessions.title: Oops, my agent did it again
sessions.description: Our industry is currently excited to put large language models into everything, everywhere, all at once. As the big headline of 2025, we have put LLMs into a virtual box and called them AI agents. These agents can autonomously do stuff in our environment, without human involvement, and use the model context protocol (MCP) to access tools. This development has some serious implications for security and safety, and we have some work to do to avoid a future where hackers are the ones laughing. Get an overview of how some of this technology actually works, how it fails and why it's a big challenge to secure it.

sessions.title: Luksusfellen for software team: Hvordan håndterer vi teknisk gjeld?
sessions.description: Teknisk gjeld oppstår av mange forskjellige årsaker. Noen ganger er vi selv skyldige, andre ganger er det organisasjonen vi jobber i eller rett og slett den evige tekniske utviklingen rundt oss som fører oss ut i ulykka. Når det er forskjellige årsaker til teknisk gjeld, må vi også håndtere disse på forskjellige måter. I dette foredraget vil jeg dele erfaringer og noen verktøy og metoder som teamet ditt kan bruke for å få et mer bevisst forhold til sin egen tekniske gjeld, og hvordan man kan begynne å jobbe med den. På samme måte som i Luksusfellen handler det om å se realiteten i øynene og begynne å lage en plan!

sessions.title: "Im In!": Why Movies and TV Get Tech So Hilariously Wrong
sessions.description:
We all love a good movie or TV show, but almost every time technology is involved, something ridiculous happens.
The hacker cracks government security in 30 seconds, the CCTV cameras zoom in to read license plates and someone types furiously at a keyboard until a satellite is compromised.
Why do writers keep getting the most basic of tech so wrong?

Join me as we dive into some infamous tech tropes from film and television and ask the question: "What if these scenes aren’t just a result of bad writing? What if they reflect a deeper truth: that explaining real-world tech is just really hard?"

If you’ve ever screamed at the screen "That’s not how that works!" then this talk is for you!

sessions.title: Ask for stories, not for features
sessions.description:
"Everybody lies" goes the famous Dr. House quote. Obviously not true, in general and specifically when we do open-ended discovery work. But psychological biases are at play when users try to answer the questions we ask them. If we ask about the wrong thing, we get the wrong answers, and we build the wrong features. 

In this workshop, we'll explore the art of story-based interviewing and generating opportunities from them. It will be hands-on, fun, and challenging.

sessions.title: Automatic Accessibility Testing for a Better Future
sessions.description:
Automatic accessibility tests will help us build better, more inclusive applications today and help us ensure that our applications continue to be accessible in the future.

In this workshop you'll learn how to set up and write your own automatic accessibility tests using Axe and Playwright. We'll cover how to set up the tests and will look at what we can find with different types of tests. While doing this we'll also cover some of the most common accessibility errors that can be discovered automatically and learn how to fix them.

sessions.title: Bygg en tilbakemeldingskultur – fra teori til praksis
sessions.description:
I denne interaktive workshopen utforsker vi hvordan tilbakemeldinger kan bli en naturlig og verdifull del av hverdagen i teknologimiljøer. Mange utviklere og konsulenter er sterke på fag, men mangler verktøy og trygghet når det kommer til kommunikasjon og personlig utvikling. Vi tar for oss hvorfor tilbakemeldinger er en kritisk soft skill, og hvordan man kan trene på å både gi og motta dem – på en måte som bygger relasjoner og fremmer læring.

Hva deltakerne lærer:

- Hvorfor tilbakemeldinger er avgjørende for personlig og faglig vekst
- Hvordan man bygger en tilbakemeldingskultur i team og organisasjoner
- Tre konkrete modeller for tilbakemelding: SBI, CEDAR og IDEA
- Praktisk trening i å gi og motta tilbakemeldinger gjennom øvelser

Verdi:

- Deltakerne får med seg et konkret verktøysett de kan ta i bruk umiddelbart
- Workshopen bygger bro mellom faglig dyktighet og mellommenneskelige ferdigheter

Målgruppe: Konsulenter, utviklere, teamledere og alle som jobber i tverrfaglige team

sessions.title: Uenighet kan være gull for å forbedre design
sessions.description:
I denne workshopen dykker vi ned i hvorfor friksjon og motstand ikke er noe vi skal unngå, men faktisk kan være drivkraften bak bedre idéer, samarbeid og løsninger. 

Mange av oss er konfliktsky og allergisk mot dårlig stemning, noe som fort kan stå i veien for ærlig samarbeid og bedre designprosesser. Åpen dialog og forståelse for hverandre, gjør at vi slipper unødvendig drama og kan holde tempoet oppe. 

Vi skal derfor: 
- Utforske hva som skjer når team tør å være uenige
- Få konkrete verktøy til å gjøre uenigheter produktive i stede for personlige

sessions.title: Fun with F# and turtle geometry
sessions.description:
Turtle geometry is made from the viewpoint of a small turtle walking on an infinitely sized sheet of paper, leaving a trace where it walks. The turtle's movements can be controlled by a small set of commands, like "move forward" and "turn".

In this workshop you will learn basic functional programming with F#, while creating geometry. We will explore algebraic data types, pattern matching, functions and recursion, all to make the turtle move. We will make polygons, fractals and space filling curves, and look into some useful theorems for these geometric shapes. You can choose to concentrate on the F# tasks at hand, or you can allow yourself to be distracted by the beautiful geometry, and continue to explore different variants of the shapes.

The geometry in the workshop is based on the first chapters of the classical book "Turtle geometry" by Abelson and diSessa.

No previous experience with turtles or F# is required.

sessions.title: Utforsk scenariobygging med brettspillet Strategisløyfen
sessions.description:
Har du hørt andre snakke om scenariobygging, men ikke testet det selv?

I denne workshopen får du lære mer om metodene bak scenariobygging, hva du bør gjøre før du starter, og hva du bør bruke scenarioene til. 
Brettspillet tar deg gjennom en produktstrategi-prosess med scenariobygging steg for steg. Spillet går ut på å planlegge oppgaver og innsats godt med bruk av spillkort og tokens. 

Har du husket alt, eller må du ta to skritt tilbake og trekke et nytt kort?

Ta med deg teamet ditt eller bli kjent med noen nye og bli med på brettspilling!

sessions.title: Registration
Conference dinner
sessions.description:
You are all invited to the conference dinner at Kulturhuset. Bring you conference badge, as this is your ticket. There is no dress code, a lot of us a nerds and are born in a t-shirt, so come as you are! 😄

Do you have any allergies, intolerances or dietary restrictions? Submit them [here](https://forms.gle/fHGVUJEsb4FmWaBq8) before 6th of March.

Welcome from the organizers

Cognitive Load Theory has risen in popularity the last few years, and rightly so! Developers and architects have much to learn from psychology. But with popularity comes misunderstandings, since few ever take the time to read the actual research. To rid us of the misunderstandings I will take you through the concepts you can use to develop a clearer vocabulary when talking about cognitive load.

session.title: A close reading of Computer Machinery and Intelligence
session.description:
In the age of the LLM, the Turing Test is more relevant than ever. But what *is* the Turing Test? How did Turing envision the Imitation Game, as he called it, and what does he see as its greatest limitations? 

In this session, Felienne will take you on wild ride through a seminal paper in computer science, philosophy and computation.

session.title: Break
Deployment i 2025 - serverløs i praksis
session.description: Deploy pleide å bety pipelines, CI-skript og YAML-filer. I dag kan det være så enkelt som å trykke på en knapp. Jeg skal vise hvordan moderne infrastukturplatformer som Vercel har gjort det mulig å shippe en full webapp på minutter, uten å tenke på servere, infrastruktur eller DevOps.

session.title: Methodology as a Straitjacket
session.description:
At some point, we started treating methodology like religion. Agile became dogma. Design Thinking turned into ritual. Double Diamond became an icon people worship without fully understanding what it means. Everyone talks about “doing it right”, but very few remember why we are doing any of it in the first place.

People fill out canvases like they are sitting an exam, and panic when reality refuses to fit the template. Teams get stuck in ceremonies they actively dislike, but keep doing them because “it says so in the book”. And when someone finally asks, “Does this actually make sense?”, they are labelled difficult.

We don’t need to burn all the methodologies to the ground. Most of them were created for good reasons. We need to remember who the methods are supposed to serve, and stop pretending reality should bend to fit the process. Use what works, drop the rest, think for yourself.

Let’s be honest here. None of us is doing pure Agile, real Double Diamond, textbook Design Thinking, or whatever methodology happens to be in vogue this month. And that is the whole point.

The emperor is naked. And sometimes, that is perfectly fine.

session.title: MCP: Universalkontakt for AI eller snarvei til Skynet?
session.description:
Model Context Protocol (MCP) er i ferd med å bli en kraftig måte å koble AI-modeller med verktøy, data og systemer på — tenk på det som USB-C for AI. Ved å standardisere hvordan modeller samhandler med eksterne tjenester, åpner MCP døren til mer kapable og kontekstsensitive applikasjoner.

I dette foredraget viser jeg hva MCP er, hva det muliggjør, og hvorfor det er viktig. Gjennom et konkret case med en MCP-server bygget for Entur demonstrerer jeg hvordan slike servere fungerer i praksis og hvilke muligheter de gir. Men med stor kraft følger også risiko: jeg utforsker sikkerhetsutfordringer knyttet til å gi AI direkte tilgang til eksterne systemer, og trekker paralleller til reelle hendelser fra plattformer som WhatsApp og GitHub.

Avslutningsvis deler jeg strategier for hvordan utviklere og organisasjoner kan utnytte MCPs potensial på en trygg måte, og unngå de mest kritiske fallgruvene.

session.title: Build your own cloud
session.description: In light of todays weakened trust in the "tech giants" and the focus on privacy and security, we will explore an alternative to the "spin it up in {Insert cloud provider here}" solution. In this talk, we will take a look at various open source tools and software that can be used to build a competitive hosting platform. Do we have to give up the advantages that the hyperscalers provide? Are there specific benefits to building it yourself? Is this only relevant for large companies with their own DevOps teams? These are questions we will explore in this session.

session.title: Help! I've Become My Own Customer!
session.description:
You are passionately enthusiastic about code and proud of the good quality you deliver in every pull request. You are also a curious soul who thrives deep down in the rabbit hole of your hobby. All hobbies cost time. Most cost money. Some cost a lot of money, but you are smart. You find a way to make money from your hobby. You need an online store. You can write the code and pay in the time spent, but how much time do you really want to pay?

This is something Christian has pondered a lot over the last 4 years since he started a coffee roastery in his garage. The hobby wasn't supposed to become a part-time job, it was just supposed to be fun. And what's more fun than cutting corners, taking shortcuts, and defining for yourself what is good enough?

In this lightning talk, Christian will talk about the experiences he has gained from his quest to become Bergen's most caffeine-obsessed developer, and how he has gained more empathy for product owners along the way.

session.title: Oops, my agent did it again
session.description: Our industry is currently excited to put large language models into everything, everywhere, all at once. As the big headline of 2025, we have put LLMs into a virtual box and called them AI agents. These agents can autonomously do stuff in our environment, without human involvement, and use the model context protocol (MCP) to access tools. This development has some serious implications for security and safety, and we have some work to do to avoid a future where hackers are the ones laughing. Get an overview of how some of this technology actually works, how it fails and why it's a big challenge to secure it.

session.title: Scaling Varnish on AWS - How Norway's Leading News Platform Handles Millions of Requests Per Second
session.description: Norway's largest newspaper vg.no successfully migrated from physical data centers to Varnish Cache on AWS, implementing large-scale clusters in Kubernetes to serve millions of requests per second. Get to know more about how the  migration delivered improved performance through optimized caching strategies and auto-scaling, while significantly reducing infrastructure costs and enhancing operational flexibility.

session.title: Do You Really Have a Team?
session.description:
Unpacking the Illusion of Teamwork in Agile Development.

Many software teams claim to be “Agile,” but in reality, they operate as loosely connected individuals rather than cohesive, high-performing teams. In this talk, we’ll explore the illusion of teamwork—how daily standups, ticket ownership, and even Agile rituals can mask siloed behavior and developer ego. Drawing from real-world examples and Agile principles, we’ll contrast dysfunctional patterns with the traits of truly collaborative teams. You’ll leave with practical strategies to foster trust, shared ownership, and team-level accountability—whether you’re a developer, Scrum Master, or leader.

session.title: Luksusfellen for software team: Hvordan håndterer vi teknisk gjeld?
session.description: Teknisk gjeld oppstår av mange forskjellige årsaker. Noen ganger er vi selv skyldige, andre ganger er det organisasjonen vi jobber i eller rett og slett den evige tekniske utviklingen rundt oss som fører oss ut i ulykka. Når det er forskjellige årsaker til teknisk gjeld, må vi også håndtere disse på forskjellige måter. I dette foredraget vil jeg dele erfaringer og noen verktøy og metoder som teamet ditt kan bruke for å få et mer bevisst forhold til sin egen tekniske gjeld, og hvordan man kan begynne å jobbe med den. På samme måte som i Luksusfellen handler det om å se realiteten i øynene og begynne å lage en plan!

session.title: npm install malware
session.description: Npm is perhaps the biggest spreader of malware targeting developers. I'll go over how malware can be spread on npm and some ways we can protect ourselves

session.title: Unplug to Recharge: The Hidden Power of Off-Screen Time
session.description:
After years working in PR, IT Operations, and DevOps, and spending time as a Scrum Master along the way, I’ve learned that uptime isn’t everything, especially when it comes to humans. When I started my software engineering studies at 30, I thought the key to catching up was spending more hours in front of the screen. It wasn’t.
I discovered that my most creative ideas often appeared when I stepped away from the keyboard. In this lightning talk, I’ll show how taking breaks can boost creativity, sharpen focus, and bring clarity to complex problems in the fast-paced day-to-day of a developer. You’ll leave with a few simple, evidence-based habits for building rest into your schedule, because time spent off the screen isn’t lost – it is maintenance.

session.title: "Im In!": Why Movies and TV Get Tech So Hilariously Wrong
session.description:
We all love a good movie or TV show, but almost every time technology is involved, something ridiculous happens.
The hacker cracks government security in 30 seconds, the CCTV cameras zoom in to read license plates and someone types furiously at a keyboard until a satellite is compromised.
Why do writers keep getting the most basic of tech so wrong?

Join me as we dive into some infamous tech tropes from film and television and ask the question: "What if these scenes aren’t just a result of bad writing? What if they reflect a deeper truth: that explaining real-world tech is just really hard?"

If you’ve ever screamed at the screen "That’s not how that works!" then this talk is for you!

session.title: Lunch
Can we architecture our way out of a chaotic reality?
session.description:
In the IT industry we have this idea that we can remove our systems from the chaos of real life, either through careful consideration of architecture or attention to detail in modelling. Thus we should create simple, or at least maintainable systems. 

We all know this isn’t what we face in our professional lives, where even the seemingly smallest detail can cause huge delays and complications. 

Join me in viewing system development and evolving systems through the lens of the chaos of reality and societal development.

session.title: Ask for stories, not for features
session.description:
"Everybody lies" goes the famous Dr. House quote. Obviously not true, in general and specifically when we do open-ended discovery work. But psychological biases are at play when users try to answer the questions we ask them. If we ask about the wrong thing, we get the wrong answers, and we build the wrong features. 

In this workshop, we'll explore the art of story-based interviewing and generating opportunities from them. It will be hands-on, fun, and challenging.

session.title: Automatic Accessibility Testing for a Better Future
session.description:
Automatic accessibility tests will help us build better, more inclusive applications today and help us ensure that our applications continue to be accessible in the future.

In this workshop you'll learn how to set up and write your own automatic accessibility tests using Axe and Playwright. We'll cover how to set up the tests and will look at what we can find with different types of tests. While doing this we'll also cover some of the most common accessibility errors that can be discovered automatically and learn how to fix them.

session.title: Bygg en tilbakemeldingskultur – fra teori til praksis
session.description:
I denne interaktive workshopen utforsker vi hvordan tilbakemeldinger kan bli en naturlig og verdifull del av hverdagen i teknologimiljøer. Mange utviklere og konsulenter er sterke på fag, men mangler verktøy og trygghet når det kommer til kommunikasjon og personlig utvikling. Vi tar for oss hvorfor tilbakemeldinger er en kritisk soft skill, og hvordan man kan trene på å både gi og motta dem – på en måte som bygger relasjoner og fremmer læring.

Hva deltakerne lærer:

- Hvorfor tilbakemeldinger er avgjørende for personlig og faglig vekst
- Hvordan man bygger en tilbakemeldingskultur i team og organisasjoner
- Tre konkrete modeller for tilbakemelding: SBI, CEDAR og IDEA
- Praktisk trening i å gi og motta tilbakemeldinger gjennom øvelser

Verdi:

- Deltakerne får med seg et konkret verktøysett de kan ta i bruk umiddelbart
- Workshopen bygger bro mellom faglig dyktighet og mellommenneskelige ferdigheter

Målgruppe: Konsulenter, utviklere, teamledere og alle som jobber i tverrfaglige team

session.title: Uenighet kan være gull for å forbedre design
session.description:
I denne workshopen dykker vi ned i hvorfor friksjon og motstand ikke er noe vi skal unngå, men faktisk kan være drivkraften bak bedre idéer, samarbeid og løsninger. 

Mange av oss er konfliktsky og allergisk mot dårlig stemning, noe som fort kan stå i veien for ærlig samarbeid og bedre designprosesser. Åpen dialog og forståelse for hverandre, gjør at vi slipper unødvendig drama og kan holde tempoet oppe. 

Vi skal derfor: 
- Utforske hva som skjer når team tør å være uenige
- Få konkrete verktøy til å gjøre uenigheter produktive i stede for personlige

session.title: Fun with F# and turtle geometry
session.description:
Turtle geometry is made from the viewpoint of a small turtle walking on an infinitely sized sheet of paper, leaving a trace where it walks. The turtle's movements can be controlled by a small set of commands, like "move forward" and "turn".

In this workshop you will learn basic functional programming with F#, while creating geometry. We will explore algebraic data types, pattern matching, functions and recursion, all to make the turtle move. We will make polygons, fractals and space filling curves, and look into some useful theorems for these geometric shapes. You can choose to concentrate on the F# tasks at hand, or you can allow yourself to be distracted by the beautiful geometry, and continue to explore different variants of the shapes.

The geometry in the workshop is based on the first chapters of the classical book "Turtle geometry" by Abelson and diSessa.

No previous experience with turtles or F# is required.

session.title: Utforsk scenariobygging med brettspillet Strategisløyfen
session.description:
Har du hørt andre snakke om scenariobygging, men ikke testet det selv?

I denne workshopen får du lære mer om metodene bak scenariobygging, hva du bør gjøre før du starter, og hva du bør bruke scenarioene til. 
Brettspillet tar deg gjennom en produktstrategi-prosess med scenariobygging steg for steg. Spillet går ut på å planlegge oppgaver og innsats godt med bruk av spillkort og tokens. 

Har du husket alt, eller må du ta to skritt tilbake og trekke et nytt kort?

Ta med deg teamet ditt eller bli kjent med noen nye og bli med på brettspilling!

session.title: From Legacy to Rust: A Real-World Backend Migration Story
session.description:
Rust is the most admired programming language.
But is it production ready? 
And is it possible to hire developers?
Can you convince management to use it?

This talk will cover our story at Zrch, where we use Rust as the main language in our backend. We will share our learnings, our migration approach and the challenges we overcame along the way.

What you'll learn:
• How our first attempt to rewrite legacy code failed (and why)
• The strategies that made our Rust migration successful
• Pain points of Rust
• Interactions with other languages
• Building a Rust team: hiring  and onboarding challenges
• Leveraging AI tools for Rust development
• If time permits, we will briefly cover frontend aspects

Whether you're evaluating a new language (like Rust) for your next project or already committed to the journey, this session offers practical insights from a team that's been there.

session.title: Hack, Learn, Improve: Inside Storebrand’s Bug Bounty Experience
session.description:
Over the past years, Storebrand has actively engaged with ethical hackers through its bug bounty program, uncovering and mitigating vulnerabilities across a wide range of systems. In this talk, we’ll share what we’ve learned from real-world reports (from surprising edge cases to recurring patterns) and how these insights have strengthened both our technology and our culture.

We’ll highlight some of the most interesting findings, discuss how we improved our detection and response processes, and reflect on what it takes to build genuine collaboration between developers and security researchers. Whether you’re a developer, tester, or security professional, this session offers practical lessons on turning bugs into opportunities for better security.

session.title: Break
To be announced
session.description: To be announced

session.title: Day ends
Conference dinner
session.description:
You are all invited to the conference dinner at Kulturhuset. Bring you conference badge, as this is your ticket. There is no dress code, a lot of us a nerds and are born in a t-shirt, so come as you are! 😄

Do you have any allergies, intolerances or dietary restrictions? Submit them [here](https://forms.gle/fHGVUJEsb4FmWaBq8) before 6th of March.

sessions.title: Break
Lunch
Break
Break
When the narcissist runs the show
sessions.description: There is a lot of talk about good and bad leadership. But what about toxic leadership? What happens when a leader doesn’t just fall short — but actively damages culture, erodes trust, and poisons the work environment? And what does that mean for the people affected and for the organization itself?

sessions.title: Day ends
Open spaces
sessions.description: A self organizing conference. QA your favorite speakers. Listen in to interesting conversations. Or dive into a passionate (and of course respectful) debate!

sessions.title: code in Unison
sessions.description:
Unison, a friendly programming language from the future, offers a few interesting new insights into what programming could be.

Most notable they are
* a new way of developing and building code
* seemingly seamless way of distributed programming
* a novel means of managing effects via abilities.

In this workshop we take you on a journey where we explore the finer details of these promises. You will get to know Unison, its programming model and the ease with which you can describe and deploy distributed programs.

You will walk away with a fresh perspective on what development could entail, with a firm grasp of a particular way of handling effects and fond memories of a thrilling workshop shared among like minded people

sessions.title: Don't panic! The Hitchhiker's guide to the terminal
sessions.description:
Once upon a time the terminal was the primary way to engage with computers. In our time graphical user interfaces reign supreme and many people can get by perfectly fine without ever using the terminal. And yet, there may come a time when you will have to use it. And I am aiming to prepare you for these times.
What is the difference between a terminal and a shell? How do you navigate your files from the terminal? These questions and many more shall be answered in this hands-on exploration of the terminal.
If you are curious about or intimidated by the terminal, this is the workshop for you.

sessions.title: Same Same, but Sustainably Different: Designing a Ferry-tale
sessions.description: What happens when you take design lessons from car dashboards and try to steer a ferry toward lower emissions? This talk dives into how familiar eco-feedback principles from driving don’t always sail smoothly into maritime contexts, and what we learn when they don’t. Discover how small contextual shifts can completely change design assumptions, and why crossing domains can spark both creativity and caution. A short story about designing for sustainability, learning from other industries, and knowing when to stop following the map and start reading the sea.

sessions.title: Svarut - en kommunal kjærlighetshistorie
sessions.description:
SvarUt er en tjeneste de færreste har hørt om – men som nesten alle innbyggere i Norge usynlig bruker. Får du et brev fra din kommune, går det mest sannsynlig gjennom SvarUt før det havner i din digitale eller fysiske postkasse.

Tjenesten ble opprinnelig utviklet av Bergen kommune, og var blant de første som ble overtatt av KS Digital, da en del av KS, og gjort tilgjengelig for hele kommunesektoren. Det ble et viktig startpunkt for det vi jobber for i dag: Å utvikle og forvalte felles, nasjonale digitale tjenester – både ved å overta og drifte gode løsninger som sektoren har utviklet, og ved å bygge helt nye tjenester fra grunnen av.

Dette foredraget forteller historien om SvarUt – hvordan en lokal løsning ble til en nasjonal fellestjeneste, og hvordan samarbeidet mellom Bergen kommune og KS Digital bidro til å forme et nytt kapittel i historien om digitalt samarbeid i kommunal sektor.

sessions.title: Solving the complexity of sharing test data
sessions.description:
When testing together with other organisations one of the challenges is sharing test data. This has become more complex as the privacy rules have become strickter. We can't share data from production copies any longer, and when everyone can create their own test data the chances that they are coordinated across different organisations will go down.
I will show how we do this at Nav when testing with other government agencies and private companies. I will give an overview of resources that are available and also show one or two examples of what we have done.
Even though Nav is a large organisation with plenty of resources this can fairly easily be replicated in smaller organisations.

sessions.title: When the cloud came home, rethinking code and consequences
sessions.description:
After years of focusing on clean architecture and efficient code, I had an eye-opening moment when plans emerged to build a massive data center down my street. It made me realize that, despite working in tech for over a decade, I had rarely questioned the environmental or societal impact of the systems I help create. Like many, I was a skilled builder but also a passive consumer of infrastructure.

In this talk, I will explore how everyday choices in code, cloud infrastructure, and system design affect far more than we realize, from security and GDPR risks to energy consumption and environmental impact. I’ll share why developers must take an active role in questioning cloud defaults, promoting sovereignty, and building greener, more responsible digital systems.

sessions.title: Reckless use of AI is unethical
sessions.description:
AI technology is being used for everything from helping people with meal planning to programming. However, if we are not conscious of what AI is and its limitations, it could have significant consequences for our future. If we blindly trust that AI data is neutral, we risk developing products and solutions that discriminate.

This talk is not a doomsday warning, but rather a reminder of the potential consequences of using AI, along with a gentle nudge to get ahead of AI's biases.

sessions.title: Easter will break your code
sessions.description:
Developers understand that dates can be tricky, but you might not realise how much havoc a moving holiday can wreak. Easter doesn't have a date at all. It moves based on astronomical rules, and drags a bunch of other holidays around in its wake. That will wreck your schedules, payroll systems, and calendar apps if you mess up.

Together we will unpack the Easter algorithm, look at how it shows up in modern software, and why a 4th century decision keeps throwing curveballs at our code. You'll walk away knowing how to calculate it and a renewed respect for how dangerous "simple" date logic really is.

sessions.title: Developer Community at a Non-Dev Company: a How-to Guide
sessions.description:
Creating a thriving professional community is essential for every workplace. It can be particularly challenging for groups outside a company's core business areas.
I am a software developer passionate about community building who works at an energy company. 
In this talk, I will reflect on what makes a workplace feel welcoming and inclusive. We will dive into good practices for establishing a dev community within a non-dev company.

sessions.title: There is more to life than KPIs
sessions.description: During an Open Space discussion at last year`s Booster Conference, we discussed the distance between leaders and teams. The gap is real, but it is not there because of bad intentions. Instead, I think the gap exists because it is difficult to see how leaders achieve control by letting go of it. Over the past year leading an area of highly skilled and diverse teams, I have put this into practice. Some things worked, others didn’t, but the consistent theme is that I, as a leader, must prove myself worthy of the team's trust. Perhaps these insights can provide value to others as well?

sessions.title: Design for endring, ikke bare engasjement.
sessions.description:
Gamification har lenge vært et fristende virkemiddel i design – poeng, badges og streaks som skal få brukere til å «gjøre mer».
Men hva skjer når disse virkemidlene ikke fører til endring – bare aktivitet?

I dette foredraget utforsker Sofija hvordan design kan fungere som endringsledelse:
Hvordan vi kan støtte reell atferdsendring, motivasjon og mestring – uten å erstatte menneskelig driv med kunstige belønninger.

Med eksempler fra helsefeltet viser hun hvordan innsikt fra atferdsdesign og endringsledelse kan brukes til å bygge løsninger som faktisk hjelper folk med å få til en endring – på sine egne premisser.

sessions.title: From clueless to queueless ⛴️
sessions.description:
In Northern Norway, you are twice as likely to miss a ferry as anywhere else in the country. Combine that with long round-trip times and a massive summer influx of tourists, and you have a recipe for frustration — and a juicy news headline.

Today’s “first come, first served” principle does not scale in the north. Through an interdisciplinary design thinking process involving locals, tourists, ferry crews, and domain experts, we aim to reimagine the ferry journey and eliminate queues across the county.

In this session, we will pull back the curtain on our innovation process and the technology driving it. You will see real-world results from our peak-season pilot, learn how it captured national interest, and leave with a kickass strategy for turning bold ideas into reality.

sessions.title: Baby steps – Making Norwegian bureaucracy run smoother one application at a time
sessions.description:
The Norwegian Labour and Welfare Administration (NAV) is one of Norway’s largest employers and are responsible for upholding the Norwegian welfare state. In this talk I'll share how we used product design methodology to design, deliver and continuously improve a digital application for child benefit in Norway by moving away from a solely paper-based application.

I’ll talk about how we gathered insight, both qualitative from real users and case managers, as well as quantitative through various different platforms. I'll also talk about the potential benefits that come with digitizing a paper-based form, and how we measured the success of our product. At the end I will show our concrete results, and reflect on how we spend the taxpayers money to make better digital services for the inhabitants of Norway.

This session is for designers, product leads and content designers who want to learn about how one of Norway’s largest government agency works to improve its products and services and how digitizing a paper form opens doors to gathering data in a smarter and more efficient ways, as well as how to use quantitative measures both to evaluate the success of your product, and as a tool to help prioritizing and improving your design.

sessions.title: Hvordan vi samarbeider som utvikler og designer
sessions.description:
Kan en designer og en utvikler virkelig jobbe sømløst sammen? Dette spørsmålet dykker vi ned i under vår presentasjon, der vi deler erfaringer fra vårt samarbeid som utvikler og designer i et tverrfaglig produktteam. Mange organisasjoner beveger seg bort fra tradisjonelle vannfallsmetoder og over mot smidige, tverrfaglige team. Likevel kan det være utfordrende å få designere og utviklere til å samarbeide effektivt når man er vant til separate prosesser med overleveringer som standard arbeidsmåte.

I vår presentasjon forteller vi hvordan vi, Jesper (designer) og Solveig (utvikler), har jobbet sammen over to år for å utvikle en tett og smidig samhandlingsprosess. Vi deler fire konkrete tips som har hjulpet oss å bryte ned siloer og bygge et samarbeid som gir bedre produkter og mer engasjerte teammedlemmer.

Dette er en presentasjon som passer for alle som jobber i eller med tverrfaglige team, enten du er utvikler, designer, produktleder eller noe midt imellom. Vi gir deg konkrete tips og inspirasjon til hvordan du kan styrke samarbeidet mellom fagdisipliner og skape mer verdi for brukerne.

sessions.title: Kreativitet kan omsettes til data (og her er hvordan)
sessions.description:
Har du noen gang hatt en dag hvor alt bare flyter...Idéene strømmer på, og arbeidet føles lekende lett? Eller en dag der det stikk motsatte skjer...hvor alt føles tungt, og motivasjonen er på bunn? Hva er det egentlig som driver disse svingningene?

Gjennom spennende arbeidslivsforskning har vi innsikt i hvordan indre motivasjon, stress og opplevelser påvirker kreativiteten vår – og til og med hva som skiller de mest innovative selskapene fra de som kollapser. I dette foredraget vil jeg dele både forskningsfunn og min egen erfaring med å måle min egen kreativitet gjennom et halvt år. Til slutt vil jeg dele konkrete tips til å styrke din egen kreativitet og indre motivasjon, både i arbeidslivet og i hverdagen.

sessions.title: It is a sociotechnical system - but what does that mean?
sessions.description:
Sociotechnical systems theory was made based on the discovery that different people use technology different. The first research report was from coalmines where new technology that was introduced made the work go slower. But then, they discovered one mine who managed to use the technology in a more efficient way, and this is an important discovery.

Because, if people work differently with the same technology, then we need to understand how to design good work. That means that we need to have design principles, not only for designing technology but for designing work systems consisting of people and technology. 

With this realization the sociotechnical systems design principles were born, and they are as useful today as they was then. These design principles are described as the conceptual underpinnings of agile, and can help us understand how to improve our work and the outcomes of our work. 

I will give examples of the sociotechnical systems design principles and talk about how they are useful for us now in designing work systems. I have a PhD in sociotechnical systems design, and try to find ways to explain them in a practical and useful way.

sessions.title: A celebration of Teletext: The first digital information platform
sessions.description:
Teletext was more than just text and numbers on the TV screen — it was a technological pioneer, and among the first digital information platforms that brought structured data directly into people’s living rooms. In this lightning talk, we look at how Teletext actually worked: from signals and data streams hidden in the TV signal, to how it inspired everything from early web portals to modern push-services.

By the time NRK shut down its Teletext service on 20 August 2025 — after 42 years on air — a piece of media history had vanished in Norway.

sessions.title: The Coastline Paradox and Software Development
sessions.description: How long is a country's coastline? It turns out that the more precise you try to measure it, the longer it becomes. But wait a minute, isn't that just like trying to estimate a software development project? Yes, it is, and actually there's a good reason for that too. Join this lightning talk to find out why, and what consequences this has for your next software project!

sessions.title: Tech debt nomads and slash-and-burn development
sessions.description: Many developers are tech debt nomads. When starting in a new role, we are righteously indignant about the shortcomings of existing solutions, preferring to burn them to the ground and start anew. A couple of years down the road, when the consequences of our own choices start to make themselves manifest and progress slows down, we find it's time to move on. To replace us come other tech debt nomads, and the process repeats itself. What fuels this process? And what are the effects on the systems we build? On the organizations that own them? On us?

sessions.title: Frontend frameworks free-for-all!
sessions.description:
Bring that shiny frontend framework that you have been wanting to try out. I'll bring some data, an API, and a sketch of what we will be building. Let's try something new!

React is everywhere nowadays, but there are so many options that does at least something better, or different. Maybe you want to try out two way data binding in Vue, enterprise frontend in Angular, make something small and fast (and without the VDOM) with svelte, resumable apps on the edge with qwik, islands with deno and fresh, or HTML as it should have been with htmx?

At work you might be tied to React, but here every framework and frontend technology is welcome. Let's build together, and share cool new findings with each other!

sessions.title: The future of design is here and you can’t see it
sessions.description:
From the 1980s until today, design has gone from not matter, to everything that matters, to not matter again. The paradigm of design seems to be changing faster than what we designers have managed to understand. What happens when we do not have any interfaces to design for? And who is actually making the design decisions for our products? 

In this lightning talk we will look at how digital design has changed both visually and conceptually in the last 4 decades and look at the key factors of what designing means in the (artificial) intelligence paradigm of the future! 

This talk is for designers, product people, and leaders who wish to understand the impact you can have on the digital future. 

Buckle up, this talk is both lightning fast and future proof ⚡

sessions.title: Brutalt webdesign, fra rå betong til HTML
sessions.description:
I denne lyntalen ser vi på hvordan brutalismens arkitektoniske prinsipper - "truth to materials",  funksjonalitet og rå estetikk, kan hjelpe oss å bygge moderne nettsider.

Etterkrigstidens brutalistiske arkitektur ble kjent for sin kompromissløse bruk av betong, eksponerte strukturer og funksjonell ærlighet. På samme måte kan brutalistisk webdesign tilby et forfriskende alternativ i dagens digitale landskap.

Vi ser på:

Brutalismens historiske opprinnelse og filosofiske grunnlag
Hvordan brutalistiske prinsipper kan overføres til kode og brukergrensesnitt

Denne presentasjonen passer for utviklere, designere og alle som liker webdesign.

sessions.title: Reglene bak et magisk design
sessions.description:
Mange designbeslutninger er enkle å forklare, som at man må ha tydelige CTA-knapper og at det er viktig å få fokus på toppoppgavene til brukerne. Men vi designere gjør også en del valg som vi kanskje ikke er like gode på å rettferdiggjøre. Har du noen gang lurt på hvorfor det er så mye luft i designet, hvorfor teksten er plassert akkurat slik og hvorfor avstanden er større her enn der, uten å få noen gode svar fra designeren? Er du nysgjerrig på hvilke vurderinger designeren gjør underveis og hvordan vi kombinerer brukerinnsikt med designprinsipper for å komme frem til et digg design? 

I denne lyntalen vil vi gi en innføring i hvordan mennesker oppfatter informasjon og hvordan vi benytter denne kunnskapen når vi designer brukergrensesnitt. Ved å gå gjennom et utvalg estetiske designprinsipper vil vi gjøre det lettere for deg å forstå designeren din og å ta gode valg på egenhånd.

sessions.title: The Art of Saying It Right
sessions.description:
Giving feedback the right way can help individuals and teams to identify strengths and areas for improvement, fostering a culture of continuous learning and development.

In this lightning talk, we will explore the BIFF model (Behaviour, Impact, Feelings, Future), a simple and effective framework for feedback by Sarah Cartwright. The BIFF model helps us move from vague criticism to meaningful dialogue, focusing on observable behaviour, describing its impact, expressing feelings, and defining a desired future action. It can be used equally powerful on positive as negative feedback. 

Through a short interactive exercise, participants will be challenged to apply the BIFF model to a realistic scenario. Together, we will explore how feedback can strengthen trust, accountability, and collaboration.

sessions.title: Dismantling the Speed/Quality Trade-off Fallacy with Systems Thinking
sessions.description:
The speed / quality trade-off fallacy gets many teams stuck in negative feedback loops -  sacrificing quality for speed, both are lost.

Teams find their backlogs filled with bugs, their stakeholders frustrated by missed deadlines and the teams themselves unhappy and stressed.

Systems thinking, and in particular using causal loop diagrams to identify the feedback loops at play can shed light on how and why the fallacy is so tempting yet so destructive.

By visualising the underlying causes of the problems, we can advocate for the practices of technical excellence - such as collaborative modelling with domain-driven design, test driven development & living documentation - that counter the pressures of the fallacy

In this hands-on lab you'll get practice working with causal loop diagrams - reading and constructing them - and collaborate together to use them to help diagnose the problematic feedback loops in your organisations.

sessions.title: Lock picking for fun and absolutely no profit
sessions.description:
Have you ever wondered how the lock on your front door actually works? This workshop offers a hands-on introduction to the inner workings of common locks. We’ll explore how pins, tumblers, and other mechanisms interact, and then move from theory to practice as participants try their hand at opening a number of padlocks on their own.

The focus of this workshop is on learning, curiosity, and a deeper appreciation of everyday objects we take for granted. By the end of the session, you’ll understand what makes locks tick, where their strengths and weaknesses lie, and why design details matter. All participants will be provided with a training lock and a set of lock picking tools to continue exploring on their own after the workshop.

We will end the session with a fun contest where the best lock picker can win a prize!

Disclaimer: This workshop is intended purely for fun and exploration; the skills demonstrated are for educational use only and must never be applied to any illegal activity.

Takeaways:
	•	A practical understanding of how common locks function.
	•	Hands-on experience with training locks.
	•	A kit to take home for continued exploration.

sessions.title: Praktisk Domain-Driven Design - Fokus på modellering
sessions.description:
Uansett hva slags rolle du har i digitale produktutviklingen er du involvert i modellering. Det går alltid en grense mellom fysiske omgivelser og software produkt and den grensen defineres av modellen som produktet velger til å beskrive virkeligheten.

I denne sesjonen vil du øve deg på modellering for å kunne bli bedre til å designe, lede og bygge digitale produkter.

Målet er å inspirere deg til å tenke fra ulike perspektive og til å foreslå ulike modeller for samme problemet du skal løse.
Vi vil gå gjennom 4 forskjellige tilnærminger til modellering, der hvert steg tilfører mer nyanse og detalj i forståelsen av problemområdet:
* Funksjonell dekomponering
* Rollebasert dekomponering
* Tids- og rollebasert dekomponering
* Dekomponering med forretningstjenester

Vi vil bruke helsedomenet til å beskrive et virkelighetsnært problem som grunnlag for øvelsen.

Siden digital produktutvikling er tverrfaglig foretak, denne sesjonen tjener på tverrfaglig sammensetning av deltagere. Du er oppfordret til å bli med på workshop, uavhengig av din rolle i software produktutviklingen.

sessions.title: Next year, you're the speaker!
sessions.description:
There is no better way to attend a conference than being a speaker. You get a free ticket, bragging rights, and best of all, the conference will treat you like royalty. You might even be invited to a fancy speakers' dinner.

But let's be honest: it's terrifying!
“I have nothing to talk about!”
“I don’t know where to start!”
“What if I forget everything and just stand there!”

The purpose of this workshop is to help you get rid of those excuses. It doesn't matter if you've held a talk before, or this will be your very first. You don’t need a to bring a talk idea. If you don't think anyone would want to hear what you have to say, this is very much for you.

When we’re done, you’ll have the start of your talk, and maybe even the spark (or panic) that makes you want to give it.

sessions.title: From Curiosity to Clarity: How to Talk to Users and Learn What Matters
sessions.description:
Everyone says “talk to your users” but what does that really mean in practice?

In this interactive workshop, we’ll explore the power of UX research through a playful, hands-on experience. Based on the classic “Wallet Project,” you’ll pair up, interview, and design for a partner’s needs, but with a UX researcher’s focus.

We’ll cover:

How to plan and run effective user interviews
The differences between research methodologies (when to use what)
How to test and interpret what you learn
How the Double Diamond helps you move from exploration to action

You’ll do research, not just hear about it, experiencing how small shifts in curiosity, questioning, and testing lead to better outcomes.

By the end, you’ll leave with:
A simple framework for running interviews
An understanding of how research fits into product work
Confidence to apply user insights to your next project

This workshop is fun, creative, and designed for everyone who wants to learn how to better learn from your users. Whether you write code, manage products, or test features, you’ll gain a fresh perspective on how to make your work more human-centered.

sessions.title: Event Sourcing: From Chaos to Control
sessions.description:
Har du noen gang jobbet på et prosjekt hvor historikken er visket ut? Ti år har gått, ingen fra det originale teamet er igjen, og ingen vet hvorfor dataen ser ut som den gjør. Vi har alle vært der. Vi lagrer dagens tilstand, men mister hele reisen – all den verdifulle konteksten om hva som har skjedd over tid.

Hva om vi kunne endre det? Hva om applikasjonen din ikke bare visste hva tilstanden er nå, men også hvordan den kom dit?
Dette høres kanskje ut som magi, men det er mulig med Event Sourcing! I denne workshoppen introduserer vi konsepter rundt Event Sourcing og hvordan det kan brukes til å orkestrere en nettbutikk. Vi vil lære å definere eventer, opprette og lytte på event-strømmer, og hvordan man kan bygge opp en database-tilstand fra eventene. 

Workhoppen er på introduksjonsnivå, og passer for utviklere som vil lære om grunnleggende Event Sourcing.

Ta med laptop med Node.js og docker 🐳 installert.

sessions.title: Hands-on prototyping med og for KI
sessions.description:
KI har endret spillereglene for hvordan vi jobber. Etter en periode med både hype og skuffelser, begynner vi å forstå hvor teknologien virkelig gir verdi for designere: I prototyping! I denne workshopen får du hands-on erfaring med hvordan du kan bruke KI til å bygge prototyper, og hvordan vi kan lage prototyper av KI tjenester. 

Som mange har erfart, er tradisjonelle designverktøy ofte begrensende. Prototypene blir enkle og brukertester handler mest om å validere våre planlagte flyter. Men når vi kobler på KI, kan vi skape prototyper hvor brukerne selv får utforske løsningen, følge sin egen flyt og vi kan observere hvordan de faktisk forstår og opplever tjenesten.

Skal vi lage gode prototyper av KI-tjenester, er det nesten umulig å gjøre dette uten å bruke KI.

I denne workshopen får du hands-on erfaring med å bruke KI i prototypingen. Vi jobber med en konkret case og du får prøve selv hvordan man kan gå fra idé til en fungerende prototype som kan testet.

sessions.title: Speaker's dinner
sessions.description: How to join: send in talk, get accepted. (Only for speakers!)

session.title: code in Unison
session.description:
Unison, a friendly programming language from the future, offers a few interesting new insights into what programming could be.

Most notable they are
* a new way of developing and building code
* seemingly seamless way of distributed programming
* a novel means of managing effects via abilities.

In this workshop we take you on a journey where we explore the finer details of these promises. You will get to know Unison, its programming model and the ease with which you can describe and deploy distributed programs.

You will walk away with a fresh perspective on what development could entail, with a firm grasp of a particular way of handling effects and fond memories of a thrilling workshop shared among like minded people

session.title: There is more to life than KPIs
session.description: During an Open Space discussion at last year`s Booster Conference, we discussed the distance between leaders and teams. The gap is real, but it is not there because of bad intentions. Instead, I think the gap exists because it is difficult to see how leaders achieve control by letting go of it. Over the past year leading an area of highly skilled and diverse teams, I have put this into practice. Some things worked, others didn’t, but the consistent theme is that I, as a leader, must prove myself worthy of the team's trust. Perhaps these insights can provide value to others as well?

session.title: Frontend frameworks free-for-all!
session.description:
